reviewText:
The game is not sad like TtM was, you should not expect ABS to the same as TtM. ABS is very funny in some parts, and is very sweet. If you enjoyed TtM, you will likely love ABS.

ABS has a very beautiful atmosphere, the areas look and feel very dreamlike to play through and the music compliments the entire setup. The animataions and the graphics feel much more advanced than TtM's, although they are still have the same retro look, they are so nicely shaded and the ground is more often than not, seemly covered in fog.

The music of ABS is very soft (such as TtM's was), and it is very playful in some moments.

There is not speech in ABS, this is one reason the music is so important, but to replace the speech, are the occasional thought-bubbles-with-pictures-in-them to show what the characters are saying. This is a very nice method, and it helps to stop immersion breaking within the game.

The storyline of ABS is about as clouded as the screen is. You can make out a story, but with the added strangness of the game, it makes some parts of the story abstract and open to a bit of interpretation, but other than that, the story is quite clear and very heartwarming.

reviewText: If you're a fan of Kan Gao's work, I recommend trying this game. Like To the Moon, this is very much an interactive story with little actual gameplay. There is no dialogue, and the themes and motifs explored in the game lend themselves to the eventual sequal of To the Moon, called Finding Paradise.\n\nThat said, this game is definitely different from To the Moon. There are no plot twists, less intense emotions, and only an hour long. I would recommend trying Gao's other games, like The Mirror Lied, to gauge whether or not a game like this might interest you. This game isn't for everyone, and fortunately Gao understands that, so if for any reason you don't like this game, you can message him for a no-questions-asked refund. I don't know if it's quite worth $4-6 for the game (+soundtrack), but I think of it as a way of supporting the work of Freebird Games, so I certainly have no regrets.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Disclosure: I got this game for free from the MacHeist Indie Games Extravaganza promotion.

Let me start by saying that, even though I will be calling 'A Bird Story' a game, I do not consider it to be one; therefore, I will not be criticising it as a game. The fact that I do not consider this piece of fiction to be a game has nothing to do with why I won't recomend it.

Without going into much detail, 'A Bird Story' tells the story of an imaginative kid that has troubles when it comes to socialise with his classmates and that saves an injured bird. This bird becomes his best friend until it has to leave. I am inclined to think the kid is autistic but that is just speculation and it could be that I am reading too much into it.

When it comes to how the story is told, this 'game' is quite competent at it. The introduction is a bit weak but it gets better as you go through the game. There is no text and no voice acting and everything is told through the environement or the movements and expressions of the characters. The game has notes of humour and can be quite cute at times but it also made me cringe other times, although that may just be me. However, there is little to no interaction and almost no exploration outside the main path. The whole piece is like a set of cutscenes and you just have to walk from one to the next one or, at best, you have to interact with a couple items before advancing and, even then, those items are marked with big green arrows or green sparkles. Any interaction feels superfluous and sometimes it seems like it would have done better without them. The game is also very short, I fully completed the game in 71 minutes according to Steam. It is so short that I did not even earn all the Trading Cards and I will have to leave it open for a while to get the last one.

The artstyle, while a bit bland looks good and represents very well what it is going on and the feelings of the different characters. The music is good, mainly piano pieces. There is one song I did not quite like but it's part of a joke and saying which one it is might ruin it if you are interested in playing the game.

Something that is unacceptable is that there is no options menu to my knowledge. I was unable to lower the game's sound and music and set the game to windowed.

My biggest problem with this game and the reason why I do not recomend it (besidesthe ones mentioned above) is how boring the story is. Why is it that most games of this genre pick stories that are so uninteresting? It is as if it was a mediocre story for a children's book but I am uncertain as if a child would enjoy or understand this game without the help of an adult. There is good talent behind this game and it pains me to not recommend it but, overall, I did not enjoy it.

A tale of the romance between a boy and his bird.

This is probably best played just as a teaser for the upcoming sequel (if ever).

reviewText:
Let's start by saying I like what Kan Gao is trying to accomplish.  I just don't think it was accomplished here.  Kan Gao would like to tell beautiful (or cute), and meaningful stories with beautiful art and music, with pixel graphics for the 'mundane' bits.  Some of that is there...  Yes, there is a pixel graphics for the engine, the music is quite nice, and there are some nice static background art.

What there isnt is a particularly interesting story this time, and the gameplay, while secondary for this kind of VN/game hybrid is simply leading you around by the nose doing things rarely relevant to the story.  I wanted to like this game, and for perhaps $1 or less (say, in a bundle), I would feel like I got my money's worth.  Unfortunately, I bought it 50% off, at US$2.50, and feel like I did not get very much for my money.  I use a $1/hour baseline, and then adjust if the game is short but amazing, or the long time is boring time.

I was bored at least half the time, honestly.  Sorry.  There it is.

I wish Kan Gao and the team success and look forward to the next game, which had a little teaser and reminded me and many others of To The Moon... Perhaps the story will be a bit deeper and more compelling than this one, as I felt I could sum it up in one paragraph.  I won't do it here, because I don't want to spoil it for anyone who may want to play.

4.5 / 10

reviewText:
It's about a boy who hates school and adults and likes to run away from his problems by escaping reality. Soundtrack is really nice but I couldn't really get into the story because it passes the limits of story reality for me.

The world, while based in the real world, is almost completely full of unreality. It makes for a nice aesthetic but stopped me from connecting with the story. Part of the magic is that the wild bird suddenly completely trusts the boy, becomes his best friend, and makes kids at his school (who previously ignored him) play with him. The bird never struggles or escapes and always goes willingly (otherwise you'd have to see the boy forcibly capture and detain it). He 'saves' the bird from the vet by running away with it because he doesn't want it to be put in a cage. He makes paper planes and flies in them (which is probably supposed to either symbolize something or be an alternative to him travelling to places).

It's probably a decent game for someone who is young or emotional but don't try to apply any adult logic to it. If you can stop thinking about things and just go with the flow you might be able to enjoy the story.

reviewText:
To paraphrase Denethor of Lord of the Rings, 'You think you are wise, Kan Gao. Yet for all your subtleties, you have not wisdom. Do you think the memories of 'To The Moon' have been wiped clean?'

Weighing in at a meager 90 minutes to complete, 'A Bird Story' clearly failed to shine brilliantly any where nearly as it's predecessor. In honesty, this game was in effect a ponderous, meanderingly minimal interactive 'adventure' that spectacularly failed to deliver.

Yes there was the broody music and the familiar gameplay but the overtly sentimental, forcefully connective tale of a boy who befriends a bird felt overplayed and, frankly, dull. This was not Kes. I felt no love for the daydreaming boy nor could I fathom the fraudulent emphasis of the boy befriending his wounded bird. This was hollow, in terms of gameplay, story and characterisation.

I sensed a genuine love from Gao about this tale, but his bludgeoningly stubborn execution, the narrow scope and, particularly, the awkwardness of shoving a falsified emotional attachments onto the gamer just made me reach for the brown paper bag.

I hope 'Finding Paradise' rekindles the oozingly flambuoyant 'To The Moon' and showcases the talents of Gao better than this ditty. Then I can consign 'A Bird Story' to the digital waste basket and turn a blind eye.

reviewText: Honestly, I can commend the obvious effort that went into this. The environments and soundtrack are beatiful and some of the mechanics are fun. But there really wasn't enough there for me to enjoy this. It's a short game (finished in just over an hour), but the the pacing is painfully slow, with cutscenes used liberally between pretty limited gameplay sequences that try to convey certain details in subtle animations but just end up making the thing drag. I think gameplay is sparse because this really isn't so much a full-out game as it is an interactive story with some gameplay elements. Not that there's anything wrong with that, but where the story is trying to be emotional and trying to draw certain parallels, it just comes across very dull and predictable. Unfortunately, when your game is heavily reliant on being story-driven, a predictable approach just kills the interest.

I loved To the Moon, and expected at least a tiny bit of what made To the Moon great exist in A Bird story. I didn't expect this.

A Bird Story's no dialogues design approach, and I do mean absolutely 0 dialogue, is what I found the most problematic. Even in AAA titles with full facial motion capture cannot convey all details into a game with just that alone . They require speeches to help. That just goes without saying that 2D sprites/ RPG maker is even less up to par with that job. No matter how much effort were put into drawing each sprites for different animations, the full intent simply does not convey well and at times it becomes tideous to guess what the characters are actually feeling with no dialogues or any text at all to understand what they are really thinking. It's like reading a Sims chat in the Sims, yes the general feeling is understandable, but I have really no idea what the character is thinking/ saying exactly, and it hurts a narrative heavy focus expierence like A Bird Story deeply.

The game continues on worse than a silent movie- (a silent movie do have at least some text to help audiences know what the actor is reacting to or thinking), with things that aren't making any sense keep on happening (moving trees, environment kept changing etc.)  makes following the story incrediably dull and hard to endure. All my interactions- as rarely as they are available, are most often meaningless and did not really make me feel any bonding with the bird, which is supposedly the character I should care about.

A Bird Story is the first game I ever requested a refund, and I truly hope Finding Paradise would turn out better.

reviewText: I wanna preface this review by saying I love To the Moon (developed by Freebird games) and I think that game is a masterpiece and that everyone should play through it at least once. A Bird Story is kind of a spiritual successor to that game, in that it was made by the same team, has the same artist and I believe was stated to be a story in the same world, albeit with no reccuring characters. The difference between To the Moon and A Bird Story though, is that the latter has no dialogue, no actual characters or tangible story to relate to. It has very few interactive elements and that makes it just feel like an unemotional, less deep version of To the Moon. I'm not one of those people who says games have to have deep mechanics or even a lot of interaction to be considered games, but to me A Bird Story just feels like 1/10th of the game To the Moon is. To the Moon's dialogue and story and characters and storytelling elements are all so beautifully done and made an emotional and touching experience that I adored. I just can't say the same for A Bird Story. It was by no means a bad experience, but it just left me kinda disappointed and unimpressed. Maybe my expectations were too high. I usually love minimalist storytelling, but to me there has to actually be a story hidden under the surface. A Bird Story is not that kind of game.

reviewText:
A Bird Story, A bird in the hand?

I’ve been really getting into indie games lately and I’ve been shocked by how many little gems there are like Besiege and The Escapists. So when I got Indie Gala’s Dragon Rock bundle one of the games that really stood out was A Bird Story.
A Bird Story is the story of a boy and an injured bird, it follows them from meeting to when the bird has healed and ready to leave. The whole story is told without words or writing what so ever and is only about 1 to 2 hours long. Its an intriguing idea and caught my interest straight away. On Steam the game has rave reviews so I was really looking forward to this one.
The graphics are 16 bit pixel style, but they are beautiful and well done, as the story is sold on its emotional content the simplistic beauty if them works just right. The developer has really workedhard on the details too, the way things move is stunning and it really draws you into this world of fantasy. But if your not a fan of the retro style you might struggle with it.

The story is a sweet tail and you will probably find yourself thinking back to your own childhood while playing it, although I’d never looked after a injured bird as a child it reminded me of events with family pets and such. And that’s really the story, its not some deep underlined story that leaves you a moral question at the end, Its just a story of a boy and an injured bird. But that’s why its beautiful, its pure childhood innocence’s and nothing more. But this does mean the story is very linear and there is little to no exploration to be done and for a 1+ hour game that’s not really surprising, but its a shame there wasn’t something for replay value.
Now I’d love to tell you how great the controls are, but unfortunately I can’t. The directional controls are done on the arrow keys, why the hell its not on WASD I’m lost to explain and to add insult to injury the action buttons are Space and Return. Its such an unnatural set-up and on top of that you cant even move in diagonals so although the path ahead of you might snake and wind your left in a situation where you can’t follow that path in a natural way. It really spoils the experience at times and that’s sad.

But my one biggest problem with this game is how it avoids text or speech in anyway, I understand that this game is sold on this ideal but why include notes you can’t read or situations that require pictures to give you some idea of what’s happening? It feels like the developer had this great idea of a communication-less story and then got lost how to tell that story, that’s a shame as I feel just by tweaking or changing some instances in the game would really fix this.
I don’t hate this game, its by no means terrible but I do feel its an incomplete or unrealized game. The story is clever and the graphics are beautiful, but there’s so much more to a game and this is where A Bird Story falls down. I’ve been struggling to decide if I can recommend this game to readers, the truth being I really want to be able to but I just can’t. The elements are there, but they are executed badly. But I must point out Steam reviews disagree with me, so maybe you should also read those.

If you enjoyed my review, you can find more at Cyberus UK[www.cyberusuk.com].

reviewText: A bird's Story is linear story game. If it’s even a game. It’s kinda hard to call it a game. It's more like a story that you get to move around in. Now, coming from someone who adored To The Moon, I really wanted to like this “game”. Sadly, i just can’t recommend this. The story in this game is that a boy finds a bird. The whole game is about the boy's friendship with the bird. The story isn’t terrible, but it didn’t grab me anywhere near the way To The Moon did. And that’s the problem. When you have “game” 100% based on the story, and the story isn’t great, it’s doomed to fail. Sure, it’s heart warming, and im sure the main point was to show some deep message about the relationship between humans and other animals. But it didn’t grab me. It didn’t ever make me want to find out what happened next. Ultimately, i quit playing with two acts remaining. I think the biggest problem with this game is that there is no voice acting. Everything is told through animations. That is fine, honestly even the story they are trying to tell isn’t great. It’s not some complex masterpiece. At least it wasn’t from the first 4 acts i played. The music is great, just like in To The Moon. The graphics have charm i guess, but they are a far cry from amazing. I guess this game is pretty charming, but being cutesy isn’t enough for me. I don’t really understand how this “game” got such positive reviews from fans. It doesn’t really have anything going for it. I guess you could try it, it’s often on sale for under $2.00. But I honestly can’t recommend this. Not even to To The Moon fanatics like myself. Honestly, im just gonna try to forget that this game happened and just be excited for whatever game is next in the franchise. What a disappointment.

reviewText:
I absolutely loved the hell out of To The Moon, so I was very much looking forward to this game, expecting I might get an experience of similar quality, but A Bird Story is... odd.

I can't give this game a definite thumbs up or thumbs down but am giving it a thumbs down mostly because steam forces you to pick one, but also it was just not personally to my taste, but that doesn't mean I would say it's BAD exactly.

The positive that it has going for it is that Kan Gao is still an incredible director when it comes to getting complexity out of simple 2D pixel characters. My favorite example from A Bird Story are the two silent interactions between the protagonist and the stranger on the elevator. It's such a small subtle thing, but little things like that give a game world huge character. Very few other games writers/directors have such great writer's perception to be able think of and effectively portray those types of subtle little human moments, but Kan Gao is an excellent director in that regard.

At the same time, though, I was also disappointed. While To The Moon was an extremely complex story with many characters, layers, and themes, A Bird Story is so simple it feels dull. To The Moon also had a certain degree of gameplay, what with hunting for memory links, solving puzzles, exploration, and some occasional mini-games. But sadly, in A Bird Story, it's pretty much just like watching a 2 hour cutscene where sometimes you press ENTER or hold down an arrow key for the movie to continue. (On more than one occasion, you can literally hold down any of the four arrow keys, and the protagonist just walks in any direction he wants. It literally doesn't matter where you want to go. It's just a movie that plays.)

The almost completely absent interactivity/gameplay might have been fine if the story was complex and compelling enough to keep you wanting to know more. To The Moon excelled at this by making you hungry for more information about Johnny and his life, what the rabbits meant, what the hackey sack meant, who Anya is, what the significance of the moon is, etc etc etc. There are so many mysteries, curiosities, and unresolved threads that you just have to keep going. But in A Bird Story you kind of know exactly what is going to happen, and it doesn't really defy your expectations or surprise you at all.

So my verdict is that A Bird Story is like watching a film that is the product of a pedestrian writer but an incredible director. It's hard to completely like it or dislike it.

To The Moon is as emotional and wonderful and beautiful as Eternal Sunshine of The Spotless Mind or Annabel Lee.

The writing in A Bird Story is unfortunately about as complex and interesting as its title. Still great direction, though.

TLDR: Do not expect to get To The Moon out of this, but you might still enjoy it depending on whatever idiosyncratic tastes you might have.

reviewText:
A short, simple story about a boy who meets a bird, and goes on a whimsicle journey together.

A fan of Freebird's previous work, To the Moon, I came to the understanding that this isn't supposed to be anything like a sequel or a full game.
But to me, there is a fine and skewed line to what can be called an 'interactive story' and a 'game', and it doesn't really impress me to cover it up with the words 'interactive pixel animation'.
Now, before you jump to conclusions - yes, I did enjoy the general feel of this game. The artwork was smooth, the controls felt acceptable, the soundtrack and sound effects were beautiful. It impressed me up until the point where the words 'interactive' were introduced.

The story follows a boy, seemingly walking a blurred line between his imagination and reality, finding a bird, and going on a whimsicle journey together. I have to qualms with the story, although it didn't really strike me much, but the interactions of the adventure felt limited to one or two directions - the game often popped up a little box showing you which direction keys, or enter/space, to press, at what time. Sure enough, you can walk up, down, left and right if you want, but you're still forced to take a certain direction to progress the story. I know it is required if you're an 'interactive pixel animation' to keep the story going, but it felt more like you were being ordered to do soemthing rather than properly interact with the pixel animation. Go left. Press space. Go right. Keep going right. Although the music gives the player some emotion whilst going through it, I was left just keeping my finger on one of the directional buttons, only to be distracted if I bumped into a tree or something. I'm not going to lie, the 'waiting period' I experienced whilst keeping my finger depressed on a directional button was met by some anticipation to get it over with. Maybe I just didn't have the patience, but a lot of it was just going back and forth, and I felt it didn't really add much to the story.


And that's another area I think the game fell short on as well - the story. It's slightly interesting, but at the same time I don't think it conveys the ideas Kao had in mind. One minute you're in your apartment, and the next you're in school, and then you're in a mixture of both - yes, the symbolism and 'blurred line between imaginary and reality' does play a part in this, but I don't think it really has a purpose. Why is this boy blurring his lines? What do the treetops coming out of the lockers mean? What is it actually meant to symbolize? With these burning questions in my mind, I became less and less intrigued with the story. It was good for the start, but I think it didn't need to keep 'blurring the lines' so constantly - so much that it was a blur altogether.

A Bird Story does have some good ideas in mind, but at this price I don't think it adds up. It isn't bad at its core, but the amalgamation of all its shortfalls makes it an 'experience' that tests your patience rather than immerse you in story. It has great art and music, and I can tell a lot of effort went into the sound effects and background art, but the linearity of the story doesn't quite do it justice. That being said, Freebird is at least offering a refunds policy to people that feel genuinely ripped off, so that's nice of him.

From this game, I can only partially see what to expect in To The Moon's sequel, but unfortunately it was hampered by what could have been a great preview of it. I wish all the people at Freebird all the best, and I'm having high hopes for To The Moon's sequel despite me feeling underwhelmed by this game.

reviewText:
Overview:
A short interactive story about a boy who befriends an injured bird and the imaginative journey they share as the bird recuperates. Light on story and extremely light on 'game' elements, this will be worth the price of admission for some, but I feel this would benefit greatly from a price drop.

Pros: For anyone who has played the amazing 'To the Moon,' this game is set in the same universe and is basically a prequel to the next full game in the series. As such, the graphics and music are familiarly pleasant.

Cons: Sadly, I can not put 'story' in the pros column. Even setting aside my high expectations from To the Moon, the story here, while cute, is both too short and too predictable to be considered a pro. Everything you expect to see happen will occur, and when the credits begin to roll it will be difficult not to feel at least a little cheated. If there were any surprises within the story, or if it had been at least a 3 hour journey as oppposed to a 45 minute one, then this might have slid by me with a recommendation, if only barely. A game like this must encourage the player to develop a strong bond with its characters, and there's just not enough here to do that. It would help if the price were lowered a bit as well. At 45 minutes, this game is like paying $5 to download a single episode of a TV series, only you'll get more story out of the TV episode.

reviewText:
It hurts me to write this review.

I loved To the Moon, and strongly recommend it. It is an original, touching story, which will entirely engage you, with lovable characters, a heartbreaking soundtrack, and perfect timing in its direction and production. Everywhere you turn, there is wonder. Kan Gao created a masterpiece there.

Unfortunately, A Bird Story has none of this. The story is cliché, utterly predictable from the start. There are only three different settings, which are repeated without any change. The musical theme is the same everywhere, and it's not very interesting. There is no character development to speak of. Worst, the pacing is just very ... off. Repeated scenes of walking through corridors towards the same place you were before. For such a short story, you would want some variety. But there is none. It's not full of wonder. It's just annoying.

Art is an experiment. There is no doubt that Kan Gao is bursting with talent. But in this case, the experiment failed. I think the attempt was to create something subtle and low-key. But it's just so subtle that the player" risks being totally un-engaged.

I guess I should say something good? The ending is quite sweet. But
date: it's also very predictable.\n\nI'm glad I bought the game (plus the soundtrack) to support video game art
recommended: but I find this very hard to recommend
hoursPlayed: even to fans of this genre of art-story games.\n\nI would like to thank the developer for supporting Linux!"

reviewText:
Bought it immediately because I was a big fan of To The Moon and wanted to support the dev. Cannot recommend A Bird Story at full price as a standalone game, nevermind as a follow-up to previous works.

Art assets and music are as strong as they've ever been and if you are going to buy the game, I STRONGLY suggest getting the bundle.

The real emphasis should be placed on the story and gameplay, and I don't think there's enough here to justify a purchase. The emotional impact of the game is undermined by the relative predictability of the story and certain elements (characters?) are introduced solely to create some arbitrary sense of conflict and urgency. There is little sense of exploration, and gameplay consists mostly of following corridors that may/may not open up and the odd bit of interaction.

There is some decent animating with the sprites to convey without dialogue, but the limited scope of the plot in general keeps that potential leashed. To The Moon's dialogue was a major strength in engaging the audience, and while it represents a considerable experiment for an author to communicate without it, it didn't do much for me.

The game caps at roughly an hour of length; I cannot recommend it at its full pricetag, as much of the experience was simply going through the motions to tell what amounted to a very basic story and a preview of the actual sequel to To The Moon.

*sighs* I wanted to like this game. I really did. I feel like I'm killing my inner self because of this, and I could barely write this review. But someone had to do it...

I played the first game that the developer created, To The Moon. It was a touching story that kept me guessing every once in a while. I liked it, and when I heard that the dev was making a spiritual successor to To The Moon, I was curious to see what it would be about.

It was either trying waaaaaaaaay too hard to be unique or not hard enough. The gameplay is basically use the arrow keys and press space. The story was WAAAAAAAAAY too... confusing, something about a boy and a bird, having no words really doesn't help this story out. There are three problems this game has that I cannot forgive, however. One is that there are no words spoken. reviewText:
There's two aspects that seem to be the options to go with any video game. 1 half is the gameplay aspect, the other is the story aspect. In this case, there really is no gameplay at all, simply walking between cutscenes and the slowest quicktime events ever. As far as a game, it's entirely unengaging.

That leaves it with if the story is strong enough to offset it, but I really don't think it is, certainly not for over an hour of game time. The idea is a 'cute' idea, but it could be done in a 5-10 minute short film far more effectively. Because of the choice to put this in 'game' format, the story progresses at a very slow pace, and the time it takes to wait for things to happen, even things like transitions from one scene to the next, is so long that I simply lose interest. There's about 30 seconds 2/3rds of the way in that were pretty entertaining, but the rest is just a slog through the story.

Without good gameplay or good storytelling, there's really not much to go on, and I rather regret the purchase. To be fair though, the developer has some good work with To The Moon, so I'll still give their next thing a try, I just hope that it's closer to To The Moon (with a strong story that offsets the low gameplay) than it is to this.

reviewText: A Bird Story feels like it's been crafted by the steady hand of legendary director Hayao Miyazaki himself, with its deliberately-paced narrative structure, disarmingly beautiful soundtrack, and imaginitive storytelling. The game is undeniably short, but its length isn't a detriment to its quality or value thanks to its low price tag and excellent pacing throughout. There's not much in terms of interaction, with most of the story being told through numerous cutscenes, but when the player is allowed to take control, it's usually to partake in a significant or meaningful event that drives the story forward. There's no branching paths or alternate routes to take, but there didn't really need to be for such a tightly focused and well-crafted narrative experience.\n\nFor the price of a movie rental on iTunes, you can get this brilliantly-executed interactive adventure game. It might even surprise you with just how meaningful and poignant it manages to be in spite of its low budget and short length.

reviewText:
A Bird Story is a sweet little game or rather story for that matter. If you
like a small emotional story, than you can definitely pick this game up, if
you're looking for a small interactive game (or any form of game for that
matter) than this is not for you.

Everyone considering buying this game be warned that this is more like a story
than a game, because the interaction possibilities are very limited for that
matter, which isn't necessarily a bad thing. Unfortunately the interactions
provided were simply so linear (you could not do any other thing except that
single interaction at a given time) that they seemed more forced than anything.

The story itself was actually extremely cliché, but it was executed perfectly
and did not leave any questions open.

The level design is the best thing about this game. It's not that the level
design was something special or breath taking but how well it was designed to
reflect the boys everyday life, especially the tunnel vision. Going from home
to school and going home back again, after some time you don't even completely
realize how you got to your destination.

The soundtrack also fitted perfectly into the game, not much to add there.

What I found to be extremely annoying though are those long pauses, moments
where your screen goes blank and stays that way for a moment. If it would have
happened once for every chapter it would have been ok, but there were moments
where it happened quite often in series which was simply put quite irritating.

All in all, I enjoyed this short little story and can recommend A Bird Story if
you're aware of its shortcomings and what this game is not.

To The Moon was much more emotional and I could connect with the story better.

Thumbs up from me.

reviewText:
A small game with a lot of soul.

The game talks a lot about childhood perception and memory.  It doesn't take long before you realize that this isn't a typical game; this is a game with a lot to say.  This game is brief and simple but there are moments that gave me pause.

To those who complain about the game's length let me ask you this: would you rather pay $5 for a one hour game that you will always remember or $5 for a longer game that you won't?  I usually don't care for game critics very much but there is a quote from Kevin VanOrd that I think articulates the viewpoint really well:

A game's length
recommended: is such a meaningless indicator of a game's value or worth."\n\nPersonally
hoursPlayed:
I would gladly pay for a brief game that leaves an impact on me.

I'll end with some pros and cons:

PROS:
+Heartwarming Narrative with Memorable Moments
+Clever usage of childhood perception in both the story and the landscape itself.
+Has a clever way of demonstrating nostalgia
voteText:
I won't spoil it.
+Sprinkles of humor help maintain narrative balance.  The humor often references other things like old TV shows and other games.

CONS:
-The player is often left watching rather than playing.
-Slow start.  This is surprising because of how short the game is
helpfulPercent:
luckily things speed up relatively quickly.
-The player is often asked to retrieve certain items or perform specific actions via visual cues.  In some cases it feels like it adds to the narrative in a meaningful way but there were a few times which felt unnecessary.

CONCLUSION:  If you like memorable artistic games with 'feels' I would highly suggest playing this game."

reviewText: By the creator of To The Moon, A Bird Story is a short prequel to the next game, Finding Paradise. While the soundtrack is well done and the story is well thought out, the lack of dialogue has a negative impact on the game. Dialogue would not fit the story fantastically, but without any clear ideas or progress I found myself distracted from the story. To The Moon had plenty of serious dialogue and would still be great without the comedic portion of it. Sadly, A Bird Story failed to draw me into the plot as well as To The Moon did. This does not mean that A Bird Story lacks other merits, I was just dissapointed that it was missing the emotion that drew me into the previous game. A Bird Story has great backdrops and sets, and in my opinion a lot of them are better than those in To The Moon. I still enjoyed the game quite a bit and I recommend it especially to anyone who has played To The Moon.

If you have an interest in RPG maker or sprite and animation work then this is a great example of what's possible.

reviewText:
There are very few games that can tell a beautiful story without any words. Games such as Journey and Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons are some excellent examples, and now we have A Bird Story.

While short, about an hour or so in length, this is a fantastic story with beautiful visuals and music. While it may not have the same impact that To the Moon had on me, it felt as though it was trying to be something different; hence the complete lack of dialogue.

On the whole, this is a quite nice, if short experience, and it is certainly worth your time and the $5 asking price. The soundtrack is absolutely worth it, as well, so I recommend picking up the soundtrack along with it.

reviewText:
Another incredible story by Kan Gao. It felt rather long for a single dream, but the feeling of being in a dream was done very, very well. I can't wait to learn this boy's life story in Episode 2 of the To the Moon saga.

While the engine is still my biggest complaint with the creations of Freebird Games (I mean really—when has RPG Maker ever been a good program?), A Bird Story felt a lot more polished than To the Moon in terms of gameplay. The game also retained the same great storytelling, but while the soundtrack was amazing, it didn't quite reach the level of awe and emotion that To the Moon did. That, however, would be a very hard feat to pull.

It was worth the long wait for this game, but now we still need to wait an indefinite number of more years for Finding Paradise. :( Oh well. We, the dedicated fans, will be here waiting, whenever it does finally see the light of day.

reviewText: A Birds Story is the heartwarming Story of a small Boy finding an Injured Bird and his efforts to try and cure it. The Game can be described as a walking Simulator , with very very little Gameplay. But especially the Sections that do have some Gameplay are very well used to strengthen the Relationship between Bird and Boy , which Ultimately makes you as the Player care. The whole Game has a Theme of childly Innocence , the Boy Character is incredibly relatable and will remind anyone of exactly what they would have done in the given Situation. That makes the Experience feel very real despite all the Surreal Elements. And while the main theme of the game is very bright and colourfull and happy , the ending gets very dark and sad to the point where i was crying from the Emotions the Game managed to convey. I recommend a Birds Story wholeheartedly to anyone who has a bit of Time to kill as the Game is very short and can be completed in about an Hour. But trust me when i say , that Hour will be worth it.

reviewText:
Short and sweet

A bird story is a 2d point and click adventure game developed by 'Freebirds' and serves as a prequel to 'Finding Paradise' (the sequel of 'To the moon'). The plot tells the story of a boy who lives a boring life, until that it is... until he finds a bird in the woods. Veterans of 'To the moon' who are looking for the same emotional rollercoaster ride in the previous game will find that this tale doesn't play with our emotions as deeply. Instead what we have is a sweet tale which maintains its ambience through out the game. Dialogue, and therefore voice acting, is absent in the game, however the sprites are used exceptionaly well to tell the story. Gameplay revolevs around moving your character and interacting with objects. There are no puzzles in this game, which I personally found was a good thing as it helps to keep the plot going forward and which is the main selling point of this game. Audio is also good with soft and sweet music played through out, similar 'To the moon'.

If you want a nice story (abit short one) or want game like 'To the moon' this game is for you.

reviewText:
I've noticed these traits in Freebird Games:
-First, the gameplay and story is slow, and you wonder what exactly the plot is.
-Then, a friendship reveals itself and you are absorbed in a wonderful whirlwind of happy.
-Finally, your emotions start to change... you notice things you didn't before, and the rollercoaster starts.

I loved this game and To The Moon. I definitely felt that To The Moon counted more on me doing things, but I cried harder and faster in A Bird Story. The music touching, the atmosphere stunning - everything around me melts and I can only focus on the screen as a beautful story plays out. Long story short - I LOVED this game, even if it did cost me a box of tissues. I will never hesitate to buy any games from Freebird, and neither should you. They have a talent like nearly no other game creators to absorb you into the story in every way possible; I will remember this wonderful game for a long time.

reviewText:
Interactive animation is definitely a good way to describe the one hour experience that is 'A Bird Story'. The plot is simple enough to follow; boy finds an injured bird and feels compelled to help it. It's cute and short. Music is moving as always and though the dreamlike state used throughout the work is different, it does not at all detract from the game's clarity. It's worth the money, and provides a nice little break from reality.

*Spoilers Below*

To those familiar with To The Moon, you're going in expecting to be broken by the end of the hour. You are completely correct. You have the knowledge of what Neil and Eva do for a living, and so when that timeline pops up at the end...you know exactly what it means. If the bird is the most difficult memory to extract, and the criticial one to retrieve, I'm already done with 'Finding Paradise' and will just resolve myself to crying my eyes out when it does eventually come out.
